13. III:30. Attempt to cross the river with Antoine in a Boat. She filled with water, and swamped. We swam to the opposite shore— I with my Pantaloons, Drawers, Shirt and hat. Antoine naked— John swam across the river, to meet us as we intended to have swum back— But he came to me on the other shore. Antoine cross’d the bridge with my wet shirt and Pantaloons, and brought back John’s Cloathes and my watch and umbrella, which I had left with him— He had also gone with a boat and found his own hat floating with his shirt and bracers in it, and one of my shoes. He had also sent a message to the house, to direct the Coachman John to come for us with the Carriage— While Antoine was gone for the Cloathes, John and I were walking and swimming up and down on the other shore, or sitting naked on the Bank. John walked over the Bridge home. The Carriage came and took me and Antoine home, half dressed. We got home, about a quarter before nine— I lost an old Summer coat, and white waistcoat, Two
two napkins and two pocket-handkerchiefs and one shoe— Antoine lost his watch, Jacket, Waistcoat Pantaloons and shoes— The boat was also lost— By the blessing of Heaven our lives were spared.

Brown. Genl. Sent for him— Proceedings of a Court-Martial upon a Soldier named Allison—sentenced to be shot for desertion. I told Genl. Brown I could not approve this Sentence. He said there was no example of a capital punishment for desertion in time of Peace— He complained that there was no adequate punishment for this offence and lamented the abolition of Stripes. Urges the increase of pay to non-commissioned officers; and said he had directed to recruit the army only from native Citizens—
I signed directed a pardon, conditional for Bryant Johnson.

div.p: For answer to the Govr. of Georgia— I sent for Mr Wirt A.G. for a consultation; but he was gone to Annapolis— Of the Adminn.Southard only is here— I proposed that Governor Troup should be answered that U.S. will not be responsible for any consequences of a Survey of Indian Territory attempted by Georgia now. Brown and Southard both concur in this; and that corresponding orders should also be given to Gaines— And also that he should keep near the spot all the disposable force— Van de Venter sent me drafts of Letters to Govr Troup and to Gaines which I revised. Brent came for the papers relating to the claims on the Colombian Government— Southard brought the draught of a charge and specifications against Captain Porter— Some of them I thought should be omitted—and others modified— By the Reports of the Commissioners of the Navy, and of Captain Tingey it is doubtful if the Frigate here can be prepared to sail with La Fayette on board, by the 15th. of Augt— Mary Buchanan dined abroad. symbols

Went with Mary Hellen and Elizabeth Adams to the Navy-Yard— The frigate Brandy-wine of 44 guns was launched. I was launched in her—at half-past nine— Lieutt. Skinner went with me on board the ship— Lieutts. Platt and Crabbe were on board— We were in waiting from Eight O’Clock when we stopped at Commodore Tingey’s house— Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy, and Commodore Morris were at the Navy-yard, but not on board the ship— The Spectators from the shore were not very numerous— I passed from the ship to a Steamboat, thence to a barge; landed at the wharf, and returned immediately home—which I reached before 11.— Force— Peter called to mention the party composition of the 4th. of July celebrators— A new Edition of the last year’s affair— Said he had seen Mr M’Lean P.M.G. who thought he should not attend either the dinner or Oration. Force shewed me also a Letter from Fayetteville N.C. on politics—

Day— I Rise between 4:15 and 5. Walk to the river— Swim from an hour to an hour and a half— Walk home— Read two chapters in the Bible, with Scott’s and Hewlett’s Commentaries— Breakfast before Nine— Dress— Newspapers— Visitors, from 8 to 10 every day— Southern Mail in the Morning— Northern at Noon— Letters— Reports from the Departments— Memorials Petitions; Solicitations for Office; for Subscriptions; for loans for donations. The day distracted with a continual succession of diversified calls, till 5 when we dine— From 6 to 7. at Billiards—from 7 to 8 or 9. wearing out the twilight in idleness; and then, retiring to bed— The temperature of the Month of June has been higher than I ever knew it

lg.l: Ira furor brevis est. Animum rege; qui nisi paret
Imperat; hunc fraenis, hunc tu compesce catenâ.
Wrath is short frenzy— Rule thy Soul—
Which must obey, or will controul.
Curb thy proud Soul, with bit and rein
ay bind him fast, with iron chain.

div.p: Saith Solomon. He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city. Prov: 16:32.

It is observable that the Heathen Poet qualifies Anger as a short madness; without discrimination or exception— He seems to forbid Anger altogether. The image of self-subjugation is the same in the King of Israel and the Roman Poet— The Christian Moralist allows anger under certain restrictions “be ye angry, and sin not— Eph: 4:26— Is it more easy to suppress this Passion now than it was in the days of Solomon, or of Horace?
